dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIG WILLIE LITTLE sits sweating on his stool in the corne of the ring. He's African-American, a heavyweight, and he cut bad under the right eye. His CUT MAN jabs coagulant into the wound; looks up to the manager standing over him

dialogues.speaker: CUT MAN
dialogues.text: I can't stop it. The manager, FRANKIE DUNN, pushes him aside.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Get outta the building, you useless tit. Frankie drops to one knee and we see his face. It's a fac that could only have been cast by generations of potato- eaters, the kind of face that survives famines and frustr invaders. Look deep into his eyes and you can see this ma has been knocked to his knees, but he's always come up be the count. Always will. Frankie picks up the kit and goes to work on Big Willie. We're mesmerized by Frankie's hand It's like watching a top surgeon going for a world speed record. SCRAP V.O. When I met him he was already the best cut man in the business. Started training and managing in the 66's, but he never lost his gift. Frankie cleans and flushes the wound with an adrenaline solution, uses his thumbs to work the blood away from the gash and packs it with a coagulant-rich salve.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: You stop it? Frankie glances at his stop watch: 36 seconds elapsed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Can't, Willie. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 2.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The RING DOCTOR wants to see Willy's face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He's fine.

dialogues.speaker: RING DOCTOR
dialogues.text: He ain't if you don't stop that bieeding. I'll give you one more round. Ring Doctor moves away as the ref whistles the five secon warning.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: What do we do? Tell me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Just let him hit you. Frankie climbs out of the ring, leaving Big Willie starin at him, confused, as the bell rings. SCRAP V.0O. Sometimes there's just nothing you can do. Willie tosses a couple of questioning looks back to Frank before he steps into punching range.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cut's too wide, too close to the bone, maybe you got a severed vein... Big Willie, unwilling to follow Frankie's instructions, k protecting his face, his opponent trying to get to the wo Frankie YELLS something from the corner. Something we can hear over the din.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...0r you just can't get the coagulant deep enough. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie reluctantly drops his guard. His opponent delivers neck-snapping blow to his cut eye. SILENCE as the camera screams into an extreme close up of Willie's wound... and that second we "hear" the coagulant being absorbed deep i the gash, “hear" the blood vessels sealing, then we fly r back out into the fight and the ROAR of the crowd. Willy backs off, looks to Frankie, who screams for him to get in there and start punching. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 3.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are all kinds of combinations you come up against down in the different layers of meat. And Frankie knew how to work every one. Big Willie lands his first solid combination and a cheer rises up.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harder thing to stop is looking.

dialogues.speaker: FACES
dialogues.text: in the crowd. Most of them ugly. Screaming for blood.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People love violence. They'11 watch a cock slash a rooster's throat; they slow down at car wrecks to check for bodies. They'll stand outside a bar, watch two friends stab each other with knives. Same people claim to love boxing. They got no idea what it is. We find...

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL
dialogues.text: fair, thin, locks early thirties; call her MAGGIE. She's standing in the tunnel, a bruise swelling on her cheek, h hair matted from dried sweat, a worn boxing robe pulled a her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boxing is about respect. Her eyes stay fixed on...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: shouting instructions from Willie's corner. Big Willie clutches his opponent, struggling to understand Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gettin' it for yourself... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie motions two low body lefts and an overhand right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 4. be

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE
dialogues.text: gets it, breaks free and:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: watches as Big Willie delivers two devastating lefts to t body, and an overhand right that sends his opponent spraw to the canvas.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.0., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And takin' it away Erom the other guy. The crowd roars as the referee counts out the opponent. Maggie shifts her lock to:

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: stepping into the ring. Big Willie picks him up and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, in jeans and an old jacket, waits outside the dre room, The door opens and Frankie steps out, calling back in:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: T'll warm up the car. And walks off down the corridor. Maggie catches up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dunn?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I owe you money?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I know your mother?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don't rightly know, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Then what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 : 5.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Twas on the undercard, won my fight, toc.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You happen to sea it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I did pretty good. Thought you might be interested in trainin' me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE,
dialogues.text: Dentt train girls.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should. People see me fight say I'm pretty tough.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Girlie, tough ain't enough. He punches through the door and walks off. Maggie watches him until the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly empty. Big Willie comes out, heads through it, pas HOGAN, a manager in his fifties, whose on his way back.

dialogues.speaker: HOGAN
dialogues.text: (shrugs} It's a mistake. Willie gives him a look and keeps walking, finding Franki pushing his piece of shit Plymouth Valiant out of the par space. Willie drops his bag on the Valiant's hood and pus alongside Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Cars should be able to back up, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Just push. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is 3  Haggis/2003 6.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: What'd Hogan want?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: He offered us a title fight.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Bout time.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I turned him down. Frankie drops into the driver's seat. Willie gets in the other side, locks to Frankie for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two-three more fights, you'll be ready.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Been two-three more fights a long time now, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You get one shot at the title, Willie. Lose, it may never come back around. Two-three more fights, you'll be ready.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: (beat, accepts it) Whatever you say, Frankie. And they drive off. SCRAP V.O. Frankie liked to say that boxing is an unnatural act...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie rides along Olympic, the only one on the bus. SCRAP V.O. That everything in boxing is backwards. For a brief second she allows the fear in; fear that she' break before she gets what she’s after.  5 Haggis/2003 7. INT. FRANKIE‘S BUNGALOW - CULVER CITY -- NIGHT With some effort and more than a little pain he drops to knee beside his single bed, crosses himself. SCRAP V.O. Sometimes best way to deliver a punch is to step back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, do your best to protect Katy. Annie, too. Other than that, you know what I want, Lord, not gonna repeat myself. SCRAP V.O. But step back too far, you ain't fighting at all. He crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post mass, the last few parishioners exit. Frankie is the last out the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Beautiful sermon, Father, made me weep.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: What's confusing you this week?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's the one God, three God thing again.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: Frankie, most people figure out by Kindergarten that it's about faith.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Is it sorta like Snap, Crackle, Pop, all in one big box?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: You're standing on the steps of my church comparing God to Rice Crispies? The only reason you come to mass every day is to try and wind me up; it's not gonna happen this morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6 Haggis/2003 8.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I really am confused about this.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: No, you aren't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: IT am.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: Then here's your answer: there's one God! Anything else, cause I'm busy?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What about the Holy Ghost?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: He's an expression of God's love.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: --And Jesus? ~

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: Son of God, don't play stupid!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Se, that makes him what, a demigod?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: There are no demigods, you fuckin! pagan! Did you write your daughter?!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: Now you're lying to a priest. You know what? Take a day off, don't come to mass tomorrow. The priest disappears inte the church. Frankie smiles and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four hip looking customers leave their table a complete m Maggie, wearing an ill-fitting uniform, steps in to bus i SCRAP V.0. Some people'd say the most important thing a fighter can have is heart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haagis/2003 3.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She scoops up the tip: seventy-five cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A basement gym on 5th Street, right in the heart of Skid Row, downtown LA. Everyone sweats, even those who are jus hanging out on the short bleachers that circle the two ri SCRAP V.0O. Frankie'd say show me a fighter who's nothing but heart and I'1l show you a man waiting for a beating. Trainers, swaying like cobras, work their fighters, isola in the noise and the steam, some whisper, others yell. Bo boxes blare different music from four corners, making it sound like a cell block.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think I only ever met one fighter who was all heart. DANGER BARCH, a scrawny young farmer white boy, throws a flurry of pitty-pat punches into the air, then announces:

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: My name's Dangerous Dillard Fightin! Flippo Bam-Bam Barch cutta Broward county, Texas-- FREEZE him in mid sentence. SCRAP V.O. Danger showed up a coupl'a years back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger steps outta the passenger seat of a beat up old Do pickup, looks around. SCRAP V.O. He'd come visitin' L.A. with Ervel, his momma's new boyfriend. The Dodge disappears in a cloud of exhaust.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Apparently Ervel got lost and ended up back in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger walks off down the sidewalk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Danger looked for him for about a week. ‘Fore he introduced himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger stands across the counter from EDDIE SCRAP IRON DU a long- retired fighter who cleans up around the gym in exchange for living in the back room. In his day, Scrap w a hell of a fighter, and he still keeps himsel= fit. He lost the sight in one eye years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: I gots nothin' against niggers.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Gilad to hear it. Scrap gives him a paper cup full of water.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: Lotsa people where I comes from does, but my mamma taught me not to cause hurt to no man, niggers or not.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You got a good mamma. Anything else I can do for you? Danger thinks hard. SCRAP V.O. It was just one of those questions you ask, but Danger wanted to give it his best answer.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: I'd likes to become the Welterweight Champion of the world. iL INT. HIT PIT - BACK TO THE PRESENT - DAY 1 As Danger unfreezes and picks up where he left off.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: -- and I challenge the Motor City Cobra Thomas Hit Man Hearns to fight me for the WBA Welterweight Championship of the whole world! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il Haggis/2003 . ii. CONTINUED: a1 SHAWRELLZ BERRY, a tough young lightweight, wraps his han as he site on a nearby bench with some gym rat buddies -- one of them his sparring partner, OMAR.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: Flippy, you ain't even ranked. To get ranked, you gotta have at least one fight.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: I'll fight any man, anytime! The gym rats laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: You're a brave man. Wanna get in the ring, go a few rounds with me? Scrap passes with a bucket, mop and bottle of Clorox.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Leave him be, Shawrelle. Danger, get back to your training.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: Will do, Mist Scrap! Danger goes back to throwing his best pitty-pat punches i the air. Shawrelle and his buddies laugh and mimic him. SCRAP V.0. Shawrelle Berry had a left hook that eould move'a tank. But he had a heart the size of a split pea. Frankie steps out of his back office, throwing a look tow Danger as he heads to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frankie bought The Hit Pit from Bobby Malone seventeen years ago. Bobby wanted to move to Florida and Frankie wanted some security. Bobby died while he was packing and Frankie found out most gyms lose money. Frankie steps behind the counter to check the log.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: {to Scrap} I thought I told you Danger couldn't work out here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: The boy's not hurting anybody.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: He's hurting me. He's breaking my heart watching him punch the air like it's gonna punch back. Frankie notices the Clorox bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How many times I tell you that bleach is bleach? Why do you have to buy the stuff that costs more?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Cause it smelis better.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's bleach. It smells like bleach! Frankie heads back to his office. Big Willie enters, nods to Scrap, who's now behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Scrap.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Willie. Scrap watches Big Willie passing a couple fighters, sayin hello, slapping hands. Willie passes a couple slickly dre managers, cracking jokes to each ether. One is SALLY MEND the other is MICKEY MACK.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Sally.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Hey, Willie. Nice fight, people are talking. Mickey doesn't look at Willie, Willie doesn't look at Mic Scrap files this away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie sits at his desk reading a small, leather bound b and trying to pronounce the words.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ta cil fionn is dhA shfiil ghiasa agat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 13.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: @ He locks up and Scrap is watching him from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of language is that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: dust thought you'd want to know you got a fighter out there not talking to another manager.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Not talking to him?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: And not just any manager, Mickey Mack.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So, you came in to tell me Big Willie is not talking to Mickey Mack.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: r Not a word, neither one of them.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm trying to read here.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: If you think that's more important. Scrap walks behind Frankie's chair, to the window that lo out on the gym.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, who's your new girl? This gets Prankie's attention. He turns and looks out at the gym. Sees:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: pounding the heavy bag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Ifd hurry; she keep hittin' it like that she gonna break her wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie works the heavy bag as Frankie approaches.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIG
dialogues.text: You wasted your money. I don't train girls.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thought you might change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE,
dialogues.text: Gotta be a dozen trainers around looking for girls, you'll have no trouble finding one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don't hardly need a dozen, boss. You'll do fine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm not your bess, se don't be calling me that. (heading off/calls) Willie, you ready to work?

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If I stop calling you boss, will you train me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Then I might just as well keep calling you it. Maggie goes back to working the baa. SCRAP V.O. She came from South-Western Missouri, the hills outside the scratch-ass (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 15. 13 CONTINUED: i3

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ozark town of Theodosia, set in the cedars and oak trees somewhere between nowhere and good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a couple patrons toss condescending looks in her direc SCRAP V.O. She grew up knowing one thing: she was trash, and she weren't never gomna be locked at anyway else. We find Maggie, in her Salvation Army street clothes, bei interviewed by the OWNER, who studies her application.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: So, you can only do dinners?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm working breakfasts somewhere else, sir. I need the rest of the day to train.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: You bathe every day?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Had another Hillbilly girl working here, all the customers complained of the stink. She never washed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I bathe every day, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Make sure you do. He walks back to the kitchen. And she doesn't let on for second how deeply humiliated she is by this. SCRAP V.0. She'd come eighteen hundred miles, but Theodosia was still just over the hill.  is 16 Haggis/2003 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie enters, passing Maggie who works the heavy bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Working the bag, boss.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Not your boss and that bag's working you. Maggie watches Frankie enter the office, goes back to hit the bag, trying to figure out what he meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie finds Scrap drinking a cup of coffee and watching Maggie through the window.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Give her her money back.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Why? How much she pay?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Six months.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: So, Lill just go give her it back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Don't be a smart ass. Woman expects me to throw away six months dues to get rid of her, she's out of her mind. Just don't encourage her. (notices) What the hell is Danger looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danger is by the ice chest, holding a bottle of frozen wa looking at the top and the bottom, as if it's one of the seven wonders of the world. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Appears to be a bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: He paying his dues?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Boy can't afford pants, you want him to pay dues?

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Get out of my office. And Scrap exits, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrap finishes mopping up and filling the soap dispensers He checks it out; all the scrubbing in the world won't ge this place any cleaner. He hits the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrap flicks the breakers and the lights in the gym cut o one bank at a time. Scrap stops as he hears something, mo out to the gym, sees: MAGGIE 1g Alone in the gym, drenched in sweat, exhausted and frustr but still working the heavy bag and looking just as awkwa She stops, breathing heavy.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Can't think of it as a bag. She looks as he walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not a trainer, but I can show you this, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Appreciate any help I can get. Scrap gives the heavy bag a shove and starts moving aroun it, maintaining the same distance as he slides forward an back, pivots and moves. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 is. 19 CONTINUED: is

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Think of it as a man; movin' back, to the side, toward you. Watch him, he’ll tell you when to hit. As it swings toward him:

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hit now, he just gonna knock you back... (demonstrates) ...smother your punches, take your balance. Don't punch until he starts away from you. Now he throws an effective combination, pivots and dees i again, each punch landing solidly. Swings it for her. She tries it, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep moving, rotate. That way your head's always movin' and you always have one shoulder back ready to fire a power shot. She fires her first effective shot. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Like that?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You get this down then start on the speed bag. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do have a speed bag. Her look telis him she doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrap opens a big locker -- inside are mops, buckets and kinds of ancient gym equipment. He pulls a worn and dusty speed bag off the top shelf.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll just borrow it till I can buy my own.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You go home now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I walk out with you?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: IT am home. She sees a cot, a chair and a Sally-Anne dresser. An anci hot plate and an even older TV fill out the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGTE
dialogues.text: It's nice. Scrap laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would it bother you much if I worked a little longer?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Just pull the door closed after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie works the heavy bag, remembering Scrap‘s lesson, t same punch, same move over and over. As...

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: watches her from the shadows of Prankie's office. SCRAP V.O. If there’s magic in boxing, it's the magic of fighting battles beyond endurance. Beyond cracked ribs, ruptured kidneys and detached retinas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus passes almost empty. SCRAP V.0. It's the magic of risking everything, for a dream that nobody sees but you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie rides, the lone passenger. Happy.  24 Haggis/2003 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie works the punch mitts with Big Willy on the far s of the room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Jab, jab, double up. Jab. Bo it again. One-two hook. Do it again. Maggie approaches the heavy bag pulling on her gloves, throwing a look to Frankie, who doesn't look back. Maggie goes to work on the bag. Shawrelle works a nearby heavybag as Omar holds. Shawrell notices Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: Hey, Flippy. Danger looks up from trying to jump rope.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Flippy, come here! I found someone you can beat!

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: I don't fights women. Shawrelle circles, looking Maggie up and down as she poun away.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: This here a woman? Let me look, you might be right, Danger.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: notices. Doesn't like what he sees, but he's not about to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: (to Big Willie) Two jabs, right-hand...

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: looks up from the comic hook he's reading. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis /2003 2h.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: There's her little titties! Barely even a mouthful.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (still working) Saw your last fight, Shawrelle. Spent so much time face down I thought the canvas had titties. Shawrelle's buddies razz him. Danger snickers.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: Canvas had titties.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWRELLE
dialogues.text: (co Omar) You gonna work or you gonna laugh? Which makes Omar laugh harder.

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: Look at me! I'm Shawrelle! And Danger falls flat on the floor, mouthing the mat. Shawrelle simmers as everyone else busts a gut.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: allows himself a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Two jabs, right-hand, hock. Do it again. Enough. Big Willie stops, breathing hard. Frankie tosses him a to uses a second to wipe off some of the sweat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll give you a rub down.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Can't, Frankie. My middle one's got piano lesson. Told Grace I'd drive her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Grace's car not working? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 22.

dialogues.speaker: BIC WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hates that car. Wants her old one back. Dealer won't do it, says he's already got a buyer.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Want me to talk to the dealer?

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate that. Big Willie heads out as Frankie takes his equipment back his office, passing Scrap.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Man‘s a rub down whore and today he don't want one?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You ever do any work around here?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Not my job I'd worry about, if I was you. Frankie drops onto the bench and starts stowing his gear the bag. Scrap pretends to just now notice Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Little girl's starting to come along.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Almost as if somebody been helping her. Maggie stops working, pulls out Scrap's old speed bag and snaps it in place.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Could be just a natural. Ask me, she's got something.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: She's got my speed bag, that's what she's got! Frankie looks accusingly to Scrap.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Now where the hell you think she got that? . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 . 23.
Frankie crosses to Maggie, who is having a hard time hitt the speed bag.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna need that bag back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This bag?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's mine. And people know it's mine, so they're gonna think I'm training you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: {still punching) That such a bad thing, boss?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Every time you touch it you lose me business.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (tries to laugh it off) I gotta agree, I am embarrassing myself. She unsnaps the bag, hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I just don't lend out my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Listen, you seem like a real nice girl, so I'm gonna give you some advice.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You may find a trainer in here or some other gym, cause they're all looking for giris, it's like the new freak show. But if they take you on they're wasting your time. You're too old. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Hagqagis/2003 24.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Den't feel that old, boss,

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well neither do I, but you don't see me fighting twenty-one year-olds. It takes four years to train a fighter. How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thirty two. Till my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't start training to be a ballerina at thirty-two, would you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Already been working it three years.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: And you can't even hit a speed bag; you had some real good training.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Never had any, boss.

dialogues.speaker: FRANETE
dialogues.text: I hate to say it, but it shows. Figure somebody should tell you the truth. Maggie tries to hide how deeply this hurts her. She fails

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry for using your bag, Mr. Dunn.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus, you're not gonna cry, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Take the goddamn bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, you need it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: IT haven't even seen it in twenty years, had three new ones since, take the damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll just borrow it till I buy my own.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Just don't lose it. Frankie walks off, angry with himself. Passing Scrap, who is smiling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You give her anything else, you're fired. Frankie slams his office door closed behind him. Scrap watches Maggie snap the bag back in and start over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie sits in his kitchen, talking on the rotary phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Hogan, your boy is the champ, so we won't split fifties, but if I don't see forty percent~- The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You call me when it's sixty forty or don't call back at all. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Frankie opens it, surprised to see Big Willie waiting, dr in his best suit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Willie?

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Something wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tris true 25

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry to come round to your house like this, I know you don't like people dropping in. but Frankie hides his discomfort. *

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're not people, Willie, you're welcome anytime.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: i wanted to thank you for getting Grace's car back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I don't know if you should thank me, Willie. Paying an extra thousand for your own car ain't much of a favor. BiG WILLIE Grace broke out and cried when she saw it. (beat) I also need to talk to you about business.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I was just on the phone with Hogan. Told him we'd be ready in September. We got everything done but the split.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: I gotta leave you, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: (blind-sided} Willie, the title is two fights away.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: It's not that. It's just like you said, I got one shot. If I win, I gotta make as much as I can while I can. I need somebody in the action, who can make things happen. (even harder to say:) And I gotta make the change before the fight. Only way this guy'd take me is he takes me to the title. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So, Willie, I got you the title fight, but this guy's gonna take you there?

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: Only way he'd do it. I'm sorry, Frankie. I know how long you been waiting for a title. I wanted it to be with me. Willie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie steps onto his front porch, watches Willie walk t his car.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mickey Mack's a business man, he can't teach ya nothing. Willy turns, a deep sadness playing across his face.

dialogues.speaker: BIG WILLIE
dialogues.text: You already taught me everything I need to know. Willie backs out of the drive as the PHONE RINGS inside. Frankie makes no move to go in and answer it. SCRAP V.O. There's some things people just don't want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's slow time, late morning. Scrap wears the punch mitts for Danger, who has his hands in the air announcing:

dialogues.speaker: DANGER
dialogues.text: ~-and I challenge the Motor City Cobra Thomas Hit Man Hearns to fight me for the WBA Welterweight Championship of the whole world! SCRAP V.O. No one had the heart to tell Danger that Hearns retired years ago.

dialogues.text: Danger, I'm wearin' these mitts for a reagon.

dialogues.text: Workin! on my footwork, Mist Scrap. Frankie enters, passing.

dialogues.text: You be thinking about that punch. E'll be right back.

dialogues.text: trying to get the swing of the speed bag, watches Scrap h to Frankie's office.

dialogues.text: Frankie opens his little leather bound book and finds whe he left off. FRANKIE. (sounding it out} Bier mé #4in leat, is n& déan do dhe armad. Scrap watches him from the door.

dialogues.text: Heard about Willie. Cold. Dead Cold. Wouldn't be such a shame if you weren't so damn old.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Least I can see through both eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Didn't do you much good, did they?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I got the gym. Don’t need to be training fighters at my age. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Willie tell you why?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mickey's got the connections.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Ain't about connections. Bout you not believing in him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I found him, I stuck with him eight years because I didn't believe in him?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Coulda got him a title fight two years ago. Man knew that. Amazing he stuck around this long.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Gettin' there and taking the belt home are two different things. I should just toss him in over his head, not protect him?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: So, you were protecting him from being champ. Now it's making sense.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: How'd your manager do for you, Scrap? You were a hell of a fighter, better than Willie, he get you a title fight? Or did he bust you out banging your head into other people's fists until you lost your eye?

dialogues.text: Thad my shot. Went out swinging, no man can say I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember. Excuse me if I didn't want my fighter spending the second half of his life cleaning up other people's spit.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're right. You're the smart one, You the one learning Greek. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Gaelic. It's Gaelic.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You just protected yourself right out of a championship fight. How you say that in Gaelic? Frankie gces back to his book.

dialogues.text: Maggie buses a table. Slips the dirty dishes into the rub tray, except for a half-eaten steak sandwich, which she carefully removes. She looks around, then wraps it in som scrap tin foil. She looks up to see the cook watching her

dialogues.text: Frankie sits on the edge of his sofa, eyes fixed on a tin TV set. There's a fight on the screen: Willie and the cha each fighter taking a lot of punishment. Frankie's face betrays every nuance of the match. SCRAP V.0. Boxing is an unnatural act. The Champ throws a barrage of punches, going for a knocko

dialogues.text: Cause everything in it is backwards. Frankie's feet shift slightly. We cut to the screen and s that Willie just did the same.

dialogues.text: You want to move to the left, you don't step left, you push on the right toe. (MORE)

dialogues.text: The champ keeps coming on strong. Willie's getting batter (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Instead of running from the pain, like a sane person would do, you step into it. The champ staggers. Frankie's feet shift forward as Willi steps right in and puts the champ down for the count. The crowd roars. Frankie turns off the set, sits back, allows himself a smile. It fades after a second.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Frankie drops into a seat at the counter, scans the menu. The counterman places half a cup of coffee before him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Since I fought Louis Typhoon Johnson at the Stadium Club in Tupelo, Mississippi.

dialogues.text: ..-That true? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: My manager ran off with the purse, left you and me to hitch home, do you remember nothin'?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Remember walkin' half the damn way. Remember thinkin' I'd be lynched.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Remember you leavin’ me with my dick in my hand behind that gas station.

dialogues.text: I got us a ride! Son of a bitch drove off before I even closed the door! Had to jump out and walk two miles back!

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Conscience got the better of you. Silence. Frankie hears a thumping from out in the gym. He gives Scrap a look.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie walks toward the dimly lit gym. Sees Maggie, swea soaked, working the speed bag, making all the same mistak and punishing herself for it. Frankie watches, unseen. Sh stops, breathing heavy. Frankie steps out into the light.

dialogues.text: You're not breathing right. It's why you're pantin'. She hides a flash of pain, something very deep.

dialogues.text: Tam thirty-three, Mr. Dunn. And I'm here celebrating the fact that I spent ancther year scrapin’ dishes and waitressin', which is what I been doing since thirteen. . (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: And according to you, I'll be thirty seven before I can even throw a decent punch - which, after working this speed bag for a month and gettin’ nowhere, I now realize may be God's simple truth. Other truth is, my brother's in prison, my sister cheats on welfare by pretendin' one of her babies is still alive, my daddy's dead and my momma weighs three hundred and twelve pounds. And if I was thinking straight I'd go back home, find a used trailer, buy a deep fryer and some Oreos. Problem is this is the only thing I ever felt good doin’. If I'm too old for this, then I got nothing else. That nuff truth to suit you? t take her eyes off him, demanding an answer.

dialogues.text: ...That your speed bag?

dialogues.text: Okay. I'll show you this, but that's it. Then you get a trainer.

dialogues.text: No, sorry.

dialogues.text: ...You're in a position to negotiate?

dialogues.text: Yes sir, because I know if you train me right, I'm gonna be a champ. seen you locking at me--

dialogues.text: --Just listen. If I take you on--

dialogues.text: God, this is already a mistake.

dialogues.text: --I'm listening, boss.

dialogues.text: If I take you on, you do everything I say. {as she opens her mouth) You don't question me, you don't ask me why, you don't say nothing ‘xcept "ves, Frankie." I'm gonna try and forget you're a girl--

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: No arguing. I teach you what you need and it's over. You go off, make a million, I don't care; get your teeth knocked out, I don't care. And I don't want to hear about it ither way. Only way I'll do this thing.

dialogues.text: She sees he can't go over this line. She shakes his hand. He moves ©. She nails

dialogues.text: He looks up at the ring, admiring Maggie. She is all lean muscle now, but her face is beet red. Frankie calls from the bleachers, waves her down.

dialogues.text: Then here you go. ito Maggie) Good working with ya, girlie. Maggie tries to keep her face from falling to the floor a she watches Frankie walk.

dialogues.text: Jesus H--Keep your left upi Your left! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: She's sitting at her table, reading a letter. We scan the words: ...neéd more money... SCRAP V.O. Truth is, even if they're wrong, even if that one thing is gonna be the ruin of them... Maggie takes the bills out of her tip jar and folds it in a letter.

dialogues.text: As Frankie comes down the stairs, passing fighters waitin for trainers. SCRAP V.0O. if you can beat that last bit out of them, then they ain't fighters at all. Frankie turns the corner, sees Maggie working the heavy b sweating like she's been at it since dawn.

dialogues.text: Woman won't do a damn thing I tell her.

dialogues.text: Why ain't you wearing shoes?

dialogues.text: Airing out my feet.

dialogues.text: You got big holes in your socks.

dialogues.text: Not that big.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I thought I gave you money to buy new ones.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: These are my sleeping socks. My feet like a little air at night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So, why you wearing them in the daytime?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Daytime socks got too many holes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: If I give you more money, will you buy socks? . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: I'd be tempted ta. But it might makes it way to the track. Couldn't say for sure. And they just keep staring at Maggie, she is a marvel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maggie KO's her next opponent. SCRAP V.O. Didn't take Maggie long te hit her stride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie knocks the next one to the mat. Girl bounces back up, Maggie puts her down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This girl goes down just as fast and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie unlaces Maggie's gloves.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Got the breathing thing down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You ain't holding your breath cause you're not in the ring long enough. You gotta quit knocking out these girls in the first round.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thought that was the point, boss.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Point is for you to get good, and to get good you need fights; and I won't be able to get you any if you keep knocking them out in the first round. Nobody wants to see their fighter embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Why am I still doing four-rounders, boss? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Because you ain't got the lungs to go six-rounds yet.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I do if I keep knocking em out in the first round. He gives her a lock. She gives him an impish smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell rings, a tough locking girl comes out of the cor heading for Maggie. SCRAP V.0. Frankie made her fight one more four- rounder, just to let her know who was boss. Maggie fakes a left hook and the girl steps into Maggie's vicious right haymaker. The girl hits the mat.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maggie left no doubt about it. Maggie heads back to her corner with a shrug for Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie faces a muscular Hispanic girl, who is dishing it as good as she gets. SCRAP V.0. Her first six rounder didn't go quite as smooth. Maggie catches her under the jaw and finishes her off.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maggie didn't knock her out till the end of the first round. As the girl is counted out:

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.0., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After that, no manager wanted to put his fighter in with Maggie.  72 73 74 Haggis/2003 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie hands an envelope full of cash to the manager sit across from him. The manager counts it. SCRAP V.O. Frankie had to go inte his pocket to get her decent fights, sweetening the purse by paying managers on the side. Frankie does the same again, this time it's another manag Then a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie's sitting at the desk, but nobody's sitting acros from him. SCRAP V.O. That only worked for so long. Then Frankie did something he hated doing. He took a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION. A deadly looking BLACK GIRL in dredlocks sta right into Maggie's soul. SCRAP V.O. And moved her up in class. Maggie jabs, snaps her left back. Jab, jab, snaps her lef back; not high enough.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That coulda been a mistake. Dredlocks comes over Maggie's left and hits her with a le weight right. And everything goes QUIET as Maggie's nose BREAKS. Maggie dances back, shakes it off as best she can but the blood is pouring. And the bell rings. Maggie drops onto her stool. Frankie is in the ring in a flash, fending off the RING DOCTOR who wants a look.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Gimme two goddamn seconds! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves off as Frankie goes to work on Maggie. The nose spread across her face; just touching it makes her wince.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's broke.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Dang! Maggie is at the point of tears, but not from the pain.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fix it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Can't. It's broken, no way to stop the blood.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tocan't. I have to calli it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I seen what you can do! Fix it!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I can crack it back in place, but I can't stop the bleeding. Ring doctor's gonna call it. She stops shouting and digs down deep into some pain we c only glimpse.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Please, Frankie. If you can stop the blood I can beat her. Everything in Frankie says don't do this. But he shoves a rag into her mouth, takes her nose between his thumb and forefinger and cracks it back into place. Maggie almost bites through that rag before he yanks it back out. Frank tries not to look into her eyes as he cleans out the bloo and packs adrenaline rich salve up her nose.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Inhale.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Inhale! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Breathe in! She does. SILENCE as Maggie sucks the adrenaline deep int her nasal cavity. By the time the sounds of the ring SWEL BACK IN she's missed half of what Frankie's saying:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- about twenty seconds before that turns into a geyser and you'll be soraying blood all over the front row. Twenty seconds, that's all you got. The ring doctor is there, does a quick check.

dialogues.speaker: RING DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay! Frankie gives Maggie one last deep look and climbs out. T bell RINGS and everything goes SILENT again -- except for the THROBBING in Maggie's ears. She strides out of her corner, fire in her eyes. Her opponent throws everything she's got. Maggie ducks and cripples the girl with two bl to the solar plexus. The girl pulls her arms down to protect her gut and Maggi hammers her in the temple. She clutches. Maggie shoves her away and delivers a lightning combinati that puts her out. The girl falls in SLOW MOTION, Maggie turns to look for Frankie. She doesn't hear him whisper:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mo cuishle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed. Maggie has her head back, cotton in her nose, an ice-pack on her face. Scrap sits between her and Frankie, who pretends to read his book. Maggie looks to Frankie:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (unintelligible) Whatcha readin'?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: {to Scrap) What the hell she say? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/20C03 58.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Wants to know what you're reading.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yeats; keep your head back.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Talk a little Yeats to her, show her what a treat that is.

dialogues.text: When the hell they gonna get to her?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (almost unintelligible) I'm okay, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What'd you learn tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (lifts ice pack) Always protect myself.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: That's the rule. What's the rule?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Always protect myself. A nurse steps into the room with a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Margaret Fitzgerald? Frankie steers Maggie over to the nurse, who walks her of

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'll be right here. Frankie sits again.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm not the one hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Broken nose don't hurt that much. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78 79 wt o Haggis/2003

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Why you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: No reason. SCRAP V.O. But some wounds are too deep or too close to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie comes out. His head's somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: (calls after him) Did you write your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Every week.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER HORVATH
dialogues.text: I have no idea why you come to church. And Frankie walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie sits, pen poised over a blank sheet of paper. He puts it down and rubs his eyes. SCRAP V.0. And no matter how hard you work it, you just can't stop the bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.0.
dialogues.text: Maggie's next two fights were easy. Maggie flattens an opponent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knocks down a second. SCRAP V.O. Maybe too easy. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie turns to Frankie, not as happy as she should be ab the win. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After her twelfth straight knock out, Frankie got a couple real good offers. The first was te fight--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLIE THE BLUE BEAR, a big-busted, masculine looking Rus pants in her corner between rounds. SCRAP V.O. ~-Billy "the Blue Bear" Astrakhov for the WBA Welterweight Title. Billie was a former prostitute, Billie comes out of the corner breathing fire.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --a banger who waded in winging shots from all angles, easily beating girls from Berlin to Australia. Had a reputation for being the dirtiest fighter in the ranks. Billie jams the palm of her glove into her opponent's nos The nose breaks instantly and the girl hits the mat.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Didn't seem to matter to her that something like that could kill a person. The crowd goes nuts.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the crowds loved her. Especially in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie hangs up the phone. SCRAP V.G. He turned it down without even telling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie's heading out. Scrap hands him the counter phone. Frankie talks, under:

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.0.
dialogues.text: The next was to fight the British champ, a Jamaican girl Billie just beat. Frankie hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He turned that down, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie pours Frankie a half a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's a lotta money, boss.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're making money. Why you still working here? She fills the remaining half with cream.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's a title match, right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You British? Then you can't take her title away; she got nothing to lese, you got nothing to win.

dialogues.speaker: MAGSIE
dialogues.text: Might still be a good fight.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I just moved you up to welterweight. Not good enough for you to fight contenders, you have to fight some bullshit champ?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Didn't notice I was fighting contenders.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I can find you another manager any time you like. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stings. Frankie knows it was a shitty thing to say. So, he has to make it worse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you learn to protect your face, I wouldn't have to turn down ali that money.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: My face out there so much, it's a miracle I ain't been knocked out yet, boss. She walks off to serve someone else, leaving Frankie to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost all the lights are off. Close on MAGGIE'S HANDS, a she winds adhesive tape around her left wrist, then lifts the roll over her shoulder and sticks the tape to the ski on the back of her neck. She pulls it down over the other side and winds it around her left wrist again, so that he glove is held up in front of her face. She pulls her righ glove on with her teeth and steps out of shot. THUD. THUD

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: bangs away at the heavy bag with her right. CUT. She's covered in sweat and still pounding, circling. CUT. Her shirt is drenched, her left is throbbing, her right hurts every time it smacks the bag. She keeps hitting it harder

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: watches from the shadows of the back hall.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You can't work here no more tonight. She stops, shakes off her glove, unwinds the tape and str it off the back of her neck, taking hair and skin with it She drops her stuff in her fight bag.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got us a reservation. Maggie looks up at him, not expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You may want to shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hair wet, Maggie sits at the counter with Scrap near the back of the restaurant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 Haggis /2003 63. oa or

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The waiter puts a cupcake down, a candle burning atop. Sh stares at it, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Ain't no big secret what you're wishing for, go ahead and blow. She does, takes a knife, cuts it in two. Scrap bites in.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thirty-three ain't so old. I was still fighting when I was thirty- nine. Fought twenty-three years. The door opens, Scrap turns to see Mickey Mack, dressed l he's been out on the town.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY MACK
dialogues.text: How ya doing, Scrap?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Doing good, Mickey. Mickey takes a seat at the far end of the counter. Scrap looks to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You two ain't talking?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Don't hardly know him.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Met Frankie just after my thirty- seventh birthday. He was picking up jobs as a cut man. He'd patch me up when I thought it was impossible. Good man to have in your corner.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, he is.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: Stayed with me through my last fight, in San Berdoo. My manager was off gettin' drunk, so it was just Frankie and me, and I was takin' a mean beatin'. Everybody got a particular number of fights in them, but nobody tells you what that number is. Mine was a hundred and nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 64.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just refused to believe it. Fourth round, this cut opens up. (points to a scar over his blind eye) Blood starts pouring into my eye. They shoulda stopped the fight, but I was a black man in San Berdoa, blood was what I was there for. So, round after round I get Frankie to patch me up, and he keeps saying he's gonna throw in the towel; but he ain't my manager, he can't throw in nothin'. Round after round, he's arguing with me and I'm damn near laughin', cause it's tearin' him up more than me. {beat} I go fifteen rounds, lose by decision. Lose my eye the next morning. (beat) In twenty-three years, he’s never said a word about it. Doesn't have to, I see it every time he looks at me. Somehow Frankie thinks he shoulda stopped that fight. Shoulda saved my eye. Lives every day wishing he coulda take back that 109th fight. I wanted to go to 110. Still do. (beat) Man loves fighters more than he loves the fight. And we love him back. But...if you wanna get to the title, maybe he ain't the guy to take you there. Maggie's stunned, never expected to hear this from Scrap. He counts out his coins and places them on the bill.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You tell Mr. Mack we'd be here tonignt?

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP
dialogues.text: You finish your cupcake. And he walks out. She watches him all the way to the door SCRAP V.O0. It's the rule. Always protect yourself. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People never take their own advice. tf she was gonna leave Frankie, better she did it to him then. The door closes behind Scrap. Maggie looks to Mickey Mack She stands and walks to him,

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Mickey Mack? I'm Maggie Fitzgerald. She holds out her hand, he takes it, swallowing his food.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hear you're a real good manager, doing good things for Big Willie. But I thought you should know that I ain't ever leaving Mr. Dunn, 30 you don't have to make any more excuses to bump into me. Sorry for interrupting your dinner. And she walks out. SCRAP V.O. Maggie always did like taking them out in the first round. And the door closes and Mickey Mack has to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie unlocks his door, picks up the mail that's heen dropped through the slot. He leafs through them as he wal into his kitchen. One of them makes him stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie opens a shoebox. It's full of identical unopened letters. He places this letter in the box, puts the box o the high shelf in his closet, alongside several similar b and closes the closet door. He sits on his bed and tries to not think. And fails. And for a first time we glimpse the crack in his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie sits in his Plymouth outside of Maggie's building wearing yesterday's suit. He checks his watch.  83 Haggis/2003 66. INT. MAGGIE'S APARTMENT -- MOMENTS LATER Bg Frankie inspects the place. He hates it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What the hell you be doing with your money?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Saving it. She disappears into the bathroom to fill up the kettle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Good girl. Frankie ambles over to the bureau, where Maggie's checkbo lies beside her tip jar. He fingers it as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When you save enough, you need to buy yourself a little house. Cash, no mortgage. He sees the entries -- most made out to Earline Fitzgeral

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Gonna be a while before I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: May be a stretch at first, but you need a place that's yours. You put it off, buy stuff that don't mean anything, what have you got? She comes back with the kettle, puts it on the hot plate.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait too long, you end up with nothin

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Soon as I get the money.

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Made a lot of mistakes in my life. Just trying to keep you from doing the same.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: T know, boss. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eo 30 Haggis/2003 67.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not gonna live forever. Hands her the video tape he's been holding.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tape of the girl you're fighting in England. You gonna get the title, we better start making some moves. She leaps into his arms, legs around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus! Get the hell off me! You know how old I am?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, boss. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: dust put the damn tape in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Put it where, boss? Frankie looks around the room. No Tv. Damn.

dialogues.text: Frankie and Maggie watch the tape. The Jamaican girl, you strong and assured, trades blows with a Yugoslav who look twice her size.

dialogues.text: How old is she?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Twenty-two.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Twenty-two? When she get to be champ?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You'll ask her when she's on the mat. The other girl's a heavyweight. It's an exhibition, charity thing. And with that, the Jamaican knocks the Yugoslav cold dead out. The tape stops. Maggie doesn't speak for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He disappe 30

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She's a good fighter.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Think I woulda been that good at her age?

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: Think you're that good now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe I missed it, Frankie. Maybe you were right. Maybe I am too old.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You could be. (standing) which woulda been a real waste of my time. , ars into the kitchen.

dialogues.text: Frankie st than him, Frankie di ands across the counter from a man ten years older a catalogue open between them.

dialogues.text: MO-CUISHILE#E. How much that gonna be?

dialogues.text: Silk. gs into his wallet.

dialogues.text: Fine. (pays it. A thought) How much extra for a harp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gL 92 Haggis/2003 6s.

dialogues.text: Prankie makes the decision, each bill he counts out causi him great pain.

dialogues.text: You want real gold thread? Frankie looks up, knowing what's coming. Waits for it.

dialogues.text: The place is so large that it dwarfs Frankie and Maggie. tapes her second hand, Maggie tests it. A PAKISTANI man with Cockney accent peeks in through the door:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: First since my daddy. I win, you think he'll propose?

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: You win, I'il propose. It was a joke, something said off the cuff, but suddenly Frankie feels embarrassed. Maggie senses it, is charmed. Frankie snatches a box out of the bag on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKI
dialogues.text: Hurry up and put this on. She looks at him, curious, then tears it open to find a K green silk robe. She turns it over, sees a golden Gaelic harp and the words Mo Cuishle emblazoned in Celtic letter

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's yours.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Nothin', it's Gaelic. Go fight. She decides to leave it at that. She flicks it open and a it unfurls...

dialogues.text: Prankie walks Maggie toward the ring. A couple of young trish men on the aisle take notice of her robe. One whisp to the other. SCRAP V.O. She wasn't the main attraction. A red-headed woman notices the robe and says something to the man beside her.

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She was on the undercard of a middleweight title fight.

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: The tough JAMAICAN punches Maggie like a speeding train. Her fists fly so fast Maggie can barely block the punches SCRAP V.O. But ask someone who was there, they couldn't tell you whe else fought that night. Maggie dances away, overwhelmed, trying to figure out how fight this girl. Frankie yells from the corner. The Jamai charges and smothers Maggie in punches. Maggie blocks and dances away; she can't get a punch off. The bell.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: hits the stool.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Dang, she's tough. I can't get inside. I can't get close enough to hit her. : (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You know why that is?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What, boss?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: She's a better fighter than you. She's younger, she's stronger and she's got more experience. {off Maggie's reaction) Now what are you gonna do about it?

dialogues.speaker: SLAM 95
dialogues.text: back into the ring. The Jamaican charges. Maggie sidestep and counterpunches, landing a stunning combination to the torso. A lone cheer comes up from the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: IRISH MAN
dialogues.text: Mo Cuishle!! The Jamaican comes back with amazing speed. Maggie blocks and counters, rocking her back with an uppercut to the ja

dialogues.speaker: SECOND IRISH MAN
dialogues.text: Mo Cuishle!!

dialogues.speaker: NOW THREE TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Mo Cuishle!!! Mo Cuishle!! Maggie looks around, confused by the shouting. With her guard down, the Jamaican connects. Maggie beats back the attack. Several more people take up the chant.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH FANS
dialogues.text: Mo Cuishle!! Mo Cuishlel! The bell.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: bangs her butt down onto the seat. Frankie pumps water in her. The Irish fans are still CHANTING.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What the hell did you write on me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Worry about the fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oo ui

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's throwing too many punches, trying to take you out early. For once in your life don't play that game. She's gonna wind down like a coy. You wait for it, then take her down.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're not gonna tell me what it means, are you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Wish I knew. Frankie grabs the stcol and climbs out. The bell sounds a the Jamaican rushes, throwing punches so fast she looks l she has four arms. Maggie blocks, then counters with a fl of her own. The Irish crowd goes wild and now almost all them are chanting:

dialogues.speaker: IRISH FANS
dialogues.text: Mo Cuishle!! Mo Cuishle!! Mo Cuishle!! Mo Cuishle!! The Jamaican staggers, Maggie presses, unleashing a gorge combination, ending in a hook that spins the Jamaican on heels and drops her to the mat. The Irish fans go wild! Maggie dances back to the corner as the ref counts the Jamaican out. Frankie grins, shakes his head. He calls up to her, but s can't hear him over the yelling and the chanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sudden silence is shocking. Frankie pulls off her glo The robe’s over her shoulders. She keeps her eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I could ask someone, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ask. If you find out, you can tell me, too. He locks down and keeps unwinding. It's a shame, because misses Maggie's beautiful smile.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Frankie unwinds the dressing and checks her hands, under: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCRAP V.O.
dialogues.text: Whatever it meant, the name stuck. Maggie fought in Edinburgh and Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam; it was always Mo Cuishle. Seems there are Irish people everywhere, or people who wanna be. By the time they came back to the States...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie fights a tough Puerto Rican girl. SCRAP V.O. Maggie was in a whole new league.

dialogues.speaker: FANS
dialogues.text: Macushla! Macushla! She knocks the girl down with a blow te the temple. The girl hits the mat and grabs her head, writhing in pain. Maggie watches her, dumfounded.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: The fans keep cheering 'Macushla', unfazed. The Blue Bear and her manager sit ringside. SCRAP V.0. After that they got another offer to fight for the title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prankie stands at the bar with The Blue Bear and her mana

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What's the split?

dialogues.speaker: BILLTE'S MANAGER
dialogues.text: Sixty-forty.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Good, we take sixty, you take forty, seeing that Maggie is the draw.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) That little girl? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PRANKIE
dialogues.text: {co Billie) You think I'm wrong? Really? You think people are saying: “I can't wait to see that scabby Russian dyke fight ‘what's-her-name'?" Lotta people in here. Find one that says that and we'll take the forty. Das Vadanya. And Frankie walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie drops into the seat across from Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: They came up to sixty-forty. They'll come back with fifty.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How's that girl doing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE,
dialogues.text: Concussion and busted eardrum.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She be all right?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What if she ain't?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Think I could send her somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You could give her the purse, probably wouldn't turn it down. Maggie gets the point. It's a hard game. Frankie looks at She does the same.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Boss? That little house we talked about? I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Smart girl.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bought it for my momma. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haggis/2003 75. 99 CONTINUED: ag

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Only about a mile from where she lives now. No mortgage, just like you said. Frankie goes back to the menu.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're a good daughter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: ...Mamma don't know about it yet. I was hoping we could stay an extra day, drive over there. I know Momma wants to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We could do that. And he hides hig thoughts in the menu.

dialogues.text: Frankie and Maggie drive in silence, passing one tiny depressed town after another until they puli into: 16k EXT. TRAILER PARK LOL They pass a line of rusted trailers; kids and dogs everyw families sprawled in lawn chairs and watching televisions They pull to a stop in front of a rusting mobile home .

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE'S CAR, (TIME CUT)
dialogues.text: The passenger door opens and a gargantuan leg swings out hits the ground, followed by a second. The back door open and an equally large leg finds the earth. We move up to s EARLINE and her daughter MARDELL emerge from Frankie's ca Mardell carries a screaming child. Her four-year old boy scrambles out of the back seat as Maggie rises from the o side of the car, her excitement obvious.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: This is the Johnson's old house.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie opens the door, bursting with pride. The four-year old runs past, Mardell waddles in after her, the baby sti (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: screaming. Earline stops in the doorway, having a hard ti understanding what's happening here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's yours Mamma. For you and Mardell and the kids. Earline enters, taking it all in. Frankie hangs back at what he hopes will be a safe distance.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: ...0h, Mary M., you bought this for me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: All yours, free and clear.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: Oh, darlin...

dialogues.text: There's no fridge. No stove neither.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: They'll be here fore you move in.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: How much money this cost you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You never mind that.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have done this.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You need a decent place.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: You shouldn't a done it. She shoulda asked me first. {off Maggie's look} Darlin', the government's gonna find out about this house, they're gonna stop my welfare.

dialogues.text: No, they ain't mamma.

dialogues.speaker: EARLINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, they are. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EBARLINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're ne, you're workin', but I can't live without my welfare.

dialogues.text: Momma, I send you money.
